Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Ultrasound-Guided Vascular Access Techniques

Trial_Design.evidence: A randomised controlled trial was conducted with healthcare providers as the unit of randomisation. The sample size was calculated to detect a clinically significant difference in success rates.

Participants.evidence: Eligible participants were healthcare providers trained in vascular access, recruited from multiple hospitals.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group employed real-time ultrasound guidance, while the control group used landmark-based techniques.

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the effectiveness of ultrasound-guided vascular access techniques versus traditional landmark-based methods in improving procedural success rates and reducing complications.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the success rate of vascular access procedures, assessed immediately post-procedure.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation concealment was ensured using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group, recruited between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 in the intervention group and 97 in the control group, using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group demonstrated a significantly higher success rate (mean difference = 15%, 95% CI 10% to 20%; p < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events occurred in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group, with no severe complications reported.

Trial_Registration.evidence: The trial was registered under number NCT12345678

Funding.evidence: funded by the National Institutes of Health
